metadata.case_name: Petition under Article 32 (Editor of Searchlight) v. Chief Minister of Bihar as Chairman of Committee of Privileges & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner is a journalist by profession and functions as the Editor of the Searchlight, an English daily newspaper published from Patna in the State of Bihar.
Petitioner published in Searchlight issue dated May 31, 1957, an account of the debate in the Bihar Legislative Assembly on May 30, 1957.
Proceedings initiated before the Committee of Privileges of Bihar Legislative Assembly against petitioner for alleged breach of privilege due to the publication.

Writ Petition No. 122 of 1958 heard and determined by Supreme Court on December 12, 1958; majority held that under Art. 194(3), State Legislature has same privileges as House of Commons at commencement of Constitution, including power to prohibit publication of proceedings.
Writ Petition No. 106 of 1959 filed by petitioner, heard on November 10, 11 and 12, 1959, but withdrawn at petitioner's request.
On January 5, 1959, petitioner received notice that breach of privilege case would be considered by Committee on February 3, 1959; hearing postponed.
Bihar Legislative Assembly reconstituted Committee of Privileges; motion sought for revival and re-reference of breach of privilege matter.

Speaker deferred ruling on objection to motion; referred questions to Advocate General of Bihar on October 20, 1959: (1) whether Assembly can debate sub judice issue; (2) whether prorogued matter can be revived.

On November 24, 1959, petitioner received fresh notice from Secretary of Legislative Assembly to show cause by December 1, 1959, why action should not be recommended for breach of privilege of Speaker and Assembly.
Committee of Privileges adopted motion on November 23, 1959.
Bihar Assembly prorogued several times between May 31, 1957 and November 23, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether the proceedings by Committee of Privileges for breach of privilege due to publication of Assembly proceedings violate petitioner's fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(a) and whether legislature has privilege under Art. 194(3) to prohibit such publication.
Whether present petition is barred by res judicata in light of previous decisions in WP 122/1958 and WP 106/1959.
Whether procedure adopted by Legislature was irregular and violative of law, and whether courts can inquire into it under Art. 212.
Whether prorogations of Assembly rendered previous proceedings dead, preventing revival.
Whether proceedings threaten petitioner's personal liberty under Art. 21.

petitioner_arguments.text: Petitioner has fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(a) to freedom of speech and expression, including publication of faithful report of legislative proceedings; Art. 194(3) privilege subject to Art. 19(1)(a); majority decision in previous Sharma case wrong.
Proceedings instituted mala fide by Chief Minister who controls majority in Assembly and Committee.
Procedure inside House not regular; after prorogations, proceedings dead and cannot be revived.
Even House of Commons privileges at commencement did not include prohibiting true reports.
Notice threatens personal liberty under Art. 21 without due procedure.
Committee reconstituted, so res judicata inapplicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Present writ barred by res judicata as same questions decided in WP 122/1958; Committee is same despite reconstitution as it acts for Assembly.
No writ can issue against Committee or Assembly for exercise of privileges.
Legislature interested in vindication of rights, not punishment.

court_reasoning.text: Previous decision in WP 122/1958 binds parties; res judicata applies even if Committee personnel changed, as it is agency of same Assembly; question affects entire Legislature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Committee of Privileges is same irrespective of personnel; res judicata gives finality.

court_reasoning.text: No fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(a) infringed as per previous majority decision; Art. 194(3) grants House of Commons privileges including prohibiting publications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner out of court on merits.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 212 bars courts from inquiring into procedural irregularities in Legislature; complete jurisdiction exists to control proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular exercise.

court_reasoning.text: Prorogation interrupts but does not kill proceedings; can be revived by fresh motion; dissolution not applicable here.
Staleness of matter for Legislature to decide; no threat to Art. 21 as no deprivation yet.

holdings.text: Previous decision on Art. 194(3) privileges res judicata; no fundamental right violated; courts cannot interfere in legislative procedure under Art. 212; prorogation does not end contempt proceedings.
Res judicata applies despite Committee reconstitution.
No inquiry into legislative procedure or timeliness.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha
precedents_cited.relevance: Majority held State Legislature has House of Commons privileges under Art. 194(3), including prohibiting publications; res judicata.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle of res judicata applies even if first tribunal lacked jurisdiction or parties differ slightly.

precedents_cited.case_name: Janardan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Non-compliance with procedure not ground for writ if jurisdiction exists.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 32 for writ; Art. 194(3) for legislative privileges; Art. 19(1)(a) claimed by petitioner; Art. 212 bars procedural inquiry; Art. 21 for liberty.

outcome.summary: The petition under Art. 32 challenging breach of privilege proceedings as violative of fundamental rights is dismissed on grounds of res judicata from previous judgment, non-interference in legislative privileges and procedure under Arts. 194(3) and 212, and revival post-prorogation.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs (implied from previous, not specified here)

key_quotes.text: "This Court held in effect that under Art. 194(3) of the Constitution a House of a Legislature of a State has the same powers, privileges and immunities as the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom had at the commencement of the Constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Restates core holding of previous decision applied via res judicata.

key_quotes.text: "The rule of res judicata is meant to give finality to a decision arrived at after due contest and after hearing the parties interested in the controversy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains basis for dismissing on res judicata.

key_quotes.text: "Article 212 of the Constitution is a complete answer to this part of the contention raised on behalf of the petitioner."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bars judicial review of legislative procedure.
